did.abstract: Managing editor of the Detroit Free Press, president of the Michigan Press Association, 1969, and national treasurer of Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalism society. Activities and topical files; speeches; papers concerning work on Cooley High School Community Council, Detroit, Michigan, files concerning Detroit race relations and the Detroit riot of 1967; papers relating to Detroit Press Club; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Frank Angelo (donor no. 4996) beginning first in 1970. Periodic additions have been received since then.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Frank Angelo Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Frank Angelo was born on September 6, 1914, in Detroit, the son of Italian immigrants. Angelo graduated from Wayne State University in 1934 and began work at the Detroit News. He started as a copy boy, advancing to become a copy editor and sports reporter.

In 1941 Angelo joined the Detroit Free Press, where he worked in the sports department until entering the navy in October 1942. After his discharge in 1945, Angelo returned to the Free Press. He became feature editor in 1950 and managing editor in 1955. During the time Angelo was the managing editor, the Detroit Free Press won a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of the 1967 Detroit riots. In 1971 he was named associate executive editor and began writing his column. Angelo retired from the Detroit Free Press in 1981, but continued to write throughout his retirement.

Angelo has been an active and influential member of several professional organizations. He was national president of the Society of Professional Journalists, Sigma Delta Chi, (1967-1970) and president of the Michigan Press Association. He has written several books including, Yesterday's Detroit, and Yesterday's Michigan, and has received many journalism honors.

Angelo has also been an active member in many philanthropic and community organizations as well as social agencies in Detroit throughout his life. These include the Detroit Science Center, the Detroit Executive Service Corps, the International Institute, and United Community Services.

scopecontent.p: The Frank Angelo papers document his career in journalism, as editor of the Detroit Free Press, his professional and community activities. The Angelo papers came to the library in several accession which have been integrated in this description.

The Personal Series sheds light on Angelo's impact on Detroit and Michigan. The correspondence file includes letters from various people which have been influential in the history of Detroit, many notes regarding various awards Angelo received throughout his career and his retirement. The Frank Angelo Tribute/Awards file contains materials and miscellaneous awards which illustrate Angelo's impact on the city, and the greater journalism community. The Navy file contains copies of the official documentation of Angelo's time in the Navy from 1941-1945. There are also materials relating to Angelo's induction into the Michigan Journalism Hall of Fame in 1987, including correspondence, a copy of his speech with notations, newsclippings, and a program from the event.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, bulk of letters from notable people offering congratulations on various awards, circa 1950-1991
Frank Angelo Tribute/awards, certificates, awards, circa 1952-1993
Michigan Journalism Hall of Fame, speech, correspondence, news clippings, program 1987

scopecontent.p: The Detroit Free Press series includes correspondence, topical files and reports relating to management of the newspaper and its role in the community. The series contains files on the 1967-1968 negotiations with the Newspaper Guild and strike, a 1961 report on women's attitudes toward the paper and analysis of the paper's readership.

did.unittitle: Detroit Women and the Free Press: A Research Report (1961)
Drafts of articles and supporting material (sample)
Manual for Regional Directors of Sigma Delta Chi
Manual for the Organization of SDX Professional Chapters

scopecontent.p: Angelo was involved in many organizations throughout his career and after his retirement. Many of these are documented in the Civic Organizations/Activities series. Angelo often wrote publicity materials and/or edited official business for many of these organizations. In this series, there are many examples of his writing as well. He served on the Board of Trustees for many organizations which are documented in this series, including the Detroit Science Center, the International Institute, and the Children's Museum. Angelo was also active in the Hand in Hand church group, the Community House of Birmingham organization, and had an interest in Entropic Technologies Corporation. Included in the Entropic Technologies subseries is the Michigan state legislative report on entropic waste management, newsclippings, correspondence, and drafts of a brochure Angelo worked on.

scopecontent.p: The Education and Teaching series consists of files on college courses Angelo taught, including one at the University of Michigan titled "The Other Detroit", consulting activities for Michigan State and Wayne State and a file on the Detroit Cooley High Parents Club

did.unittitle: Highway Traffic Safety Center Advisory Committee 1971
University of Michigan course--"The Other Detroit." 1976
Report--"To Educate the People" (with Otto Feinstein)

scopecontent.p: The visual materials series includes personal photographs of Angelo and his family and also copyprints of photographs collected by Angelo to be used in his various writings about Michigan and Detroit. There are also a few original photographs given to Angelo. Of most interest here are images of radio and television broadcasts of "The Lone Ranger" radio program and a television cooking program originating from Detroit.

did.unittitle: Photographs (mainly copyprints collected for use in various writings about Detroit and Michigan)
Lone Ranger; radio; miscellaneous Dick Osgood photos
Upper Peninsula (mainly Sault Ste. Marie and Houghton, Michigan)

Tribute to Judd Arnett September 22, 1983 a benefit for Cleary College, hosted by Sonny Eliot, with featured speakers Judd Arnett, Gilbert Bursley, Frank Angelo, Richard Chrysler, J.P. McCarthy, Tom Kizer, William McLean, Jerry Rideout, Neal Shine, and G. Mennen Williams

physdesc.physfacet: VHS videocassette, poor picture and sound quality

scopecontent.p: The Writing series includes materials which document Angelo's writing during and after his stint at the Detroit Free Press. In this series, there is a folder of columns (approximately 90% from 1979) Angelo wrote while he was at the Detroit Free Press, drafts of columns, editing projects he worked on, and speeches. Many of the materials in these files contain notations, corrections, and remarks written by Angelo with his distinctive felt tip pen. This series also has folders with materials from Angelo's other writing projects including the entry he wrote for "Detroit" in the Encyclopedia Britannica and the From Bloomfield to Birmingham book. The largest subseries is the materials relating to Yesterday's Detroit. This subseries contains chapter drafts with corrections and correspondence, research and photo agreements, reviews, correspondence with Seeman Publishing, and reviews. The correspondence with Seeman Publishing documents Angelo's decision to write the book through the editing process and final publication of the book.

did.unittitle: "It's Time to Listen, At Last, to the soft, Unheard Voices," 1967
